node.title: The year in review: Top news stories of 2021 month-by-month
node.description: "Sunday Morning" host Jane Pauley looks back on key events of a dramatic year.
node.content: ["\"Sunday Morning\" host Jane Pauley looks back on key events of a dramatic year:", "In January Joe Biden was inaugurated as our 46th president \u2026 ", "\u2026 just two weeks after supporters of former President Trump stormed the U.S. Capitol in an attempt to overturn the results of the 2020 election.\u00a0", "In February, the United States formally re-joined the Paris Climate Agreement, an international treaty aimed at limiting global warming.\u00a0 ", "The container ship Ever Given ran aground in the Suez Canal in March, holding up billions in trade. The ship was freed six days later.\u00a0 ", "In April, a Minneapolis jury found former police officer Derek Chauvin guilty of murdering George Floyd a year earlier. ", "May saw the successful splashdown of the first operational spaceflight by a private company, Elon Musk's SpaceX.\u00a0", "June saw the partial collapse of a 12-story condominium in Surfside, Florida, killing 98 residents.\u00a0 ", "July brought the 32nd Summer Olympic games to Tokyo, a year after being postponed. The U.S. topped the medal count with 113.\u00a0 ", "August saw the withdrawal of American troops from Afghanistan after a two-decade war that took the lives of over 2,400 U.S. service personnel. ", "September saw the implementation of the Texas Heartbeat Act, which bans abortions after roughly six weeks. The Supreme Court has declined to block the law, saying it's a question for lower courts.", "October brought the welcome news that the World Health Organization had endorsed the world's first vaccine against malaria.\u00a0", "In November, the Atlanta Braves won their fourth World Series, defeating the Houston Astros four games to two.\u00a0 ", "In December, tornadoes ripped through the South and Midwest, killing at least 91 people ...\u00a0 \u00a0", "...and the FDA authorized two pills to treat COVID-19, a potential game-changer in our now years-long fight against the disease.", "\u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0Story produced by Robert Marston. Editor: Chad Cardin.\u00a0", "For Breaking News & Analysis Download the Free CBS News app"]
